title: Tavares
common: Family that were owner of Santa Maria de Chãs de Tavares — Portugal. Actually, it is accepted that the family had origin with couple Pedro Viegas and Teresa de Vila Maior, but their son, Estevão Peres de Taavares, was the first to use the surname (dos Santos Rocha, Rui Miguel L. B., 2017, pp. 165 ; Herculano, Alexandre, Inqvisitiones, 1860, Volvmen I, Pars II, pp. 893).

families.name: Tavares (Lamego - Viseu)
history: The 1258 Inquiries cite that Santa Maria de Chãs de Tavares was owned by the family (Herculano, Alexandre, Inqvisitiones, 1860, Volvmen I, Pars II, pp. 805-806 ; dos Santos Rocha, Rui Miguel L. B., 2017, pp. 165), but additional data is given during 1288 inquiries, according to them, Estevão Peres de Tavares's grandfather owned the region (Torre do Tombo, Iquirições Gerais, D. Dinis, Livro 4, img. 87 - 88).

people.name: Pero Viegas
history: When Fray Bernardo de Britto cites Tavares' family, he informs that the lineage possibly had the origin with "Pedro Viegas de Tauares". To support this, he cites a donation to Salzeda in the year of 1203 "do anno de mil & duzentos & tres" (Britto, Bernardo de, 1632, fl. 233v).

When we talk about Pedro Viegas' parents, there are different proposes, so it is applied the scientific method to evaluate them:
  • The scientific method starts with the hypotheses:
    • HYPOTHESIS 1: has as basis the Fray Bernardo de Britto conclusions. To reach them, it was used patronymic and time that lived Egas, Bufa, and Mor Pais de Curveira (Britto, Bernardo de, 1632, fl. 233v). Some authors also name Egas, Bufa, as Egas Garcia da Fonseca (Felgueiras, Gaio, 1939, Tomo 27, pp. 153 ; Faria, Antonio M., 1987, pp. 516), but it is not possible to discard the possibility of his name to be Egas Gomes Barroso (Pizarro, José Augusto de S., 1997, Volume 2, pp. 610 - 611 ; Neto, Cláudio, 2014, pp. 260).
    • HYPOTHESIS 2: made by Manuel Abranches de Soveral, where he would be son of Egas Mendes [de Ribadouro] (Abranches de Soveral, Manuel, 2003, Ribadouro).
  • After having the hypotheses, it is necessary to look for primary sources that allow to confirm them:
    • HYPOTHESIS 1: When Fray Bernardo de Brito made this hypothesisiis, he said explicitly that this was a possibility "Dom Pedro Viegas podia ser filho de Dom Egas Bufa" (Britto, Bernardo de, 1632, fl. 233v), and he did not give any proof of this relationship.
    • HYPOTHESIS 2: Don Dinis' inquiries informs us that Calvo, Estevão Peres de Tavares' grandfather, owned Tavares region (Abranches de Soveral, Manuel, 2003, Ribadouro ; Torre do Tombo, Iquirições Gerais, D. Dinis, Livro 4, img. 87 - 88). Through Afonso III's inquiries it is known that "Menendus Gunsalvi de Afonsica et Stephanus Petri de Taavares sunt patroni" both Tavares and Fonseca had shared patronate of Santa Maria de Villa Maior (Merendeiro, Cristina João B., 2021, pp. 78, 115 ; Herculano, Alexandre, Inqvisitiones, 1860, Volvmen I, Pars II, Fascicvlvs VI, pp. 805-806). The Fonseca's family are possible descendants of Ribadouro's family (Pizarro, José Augusto de S., 1997, Volume 1, pp. 491 - 509). Documentation available in Santa Maria de Salzedas monastery also helps this hypothesis: The monastery was granted to Egas Moniz's widow (Merendeiro, Cristina João B., 2021, pp. 15 - 16). A few years later, his possible grandson, Egas Mendes, confirms a donation to the same monastery (Pizarro, José Augusto de S., 1997, Volume 1, pp. 490 - 491). Considering the patronymic, this Egas Mendes could be Pero Viegas' father, and using the same logic, Estevão Peres de Tavares could be his son, according to Manuel Abranches de Soveral (Abranches de Soveral, Manuel, 2003, Ribadouro). Using one more time the patronymic, Egas Mendes could be Gonçalo Viegas' father. Gonçalo Viegas grew up in Fonseca (Pizarro, José Augusto de S., 1997, Volume 1, pp. 492 ; Herculano, Alexandre, Inqvisitiones, 1860, Volvmen I, Pars II, Fascicvlvs VII, pp. 991), and his children began to use the surname from this region. One of his children, Mem Gonçalves da Fonseca, was already cited in this study (Pizarro, José Augusto de S., 1997, Volume 1, pp. 491 - 493), as a person sharing patronate with his possible cousin and brother-in-law, Estevão Peres de Tavares.
  • The THEORY is made using primary sources and comparing them with the hypotheses:
    • The HYPOTHESIS 1 has some issues:
      1. There is not any documentation to support the relationship between Pero Viegas and Egas, Buffa.
      2. Count D. Pedro informs that Egas, Buffa, had a unique son, that is homonymous of Egas Mendes' possible son, and both did not sign the surname Fonseca (Sousa, Manuel. et al., 1646, Dom Pedro, pp. 402). Probably this homonymous son was the origin of confusion that the owner's of Leomil were the same owner of Fonseca.
      3. The first people known to sign the surname Fonseca were Gonçalves Viegas' children (Abranches de Soveral, Manuel, 2003, Ribadouro ; Pizarro, José Augusto de S., 1997, Volume 1, pp. 491 - 493). Gonçalo could be a supposed brother of Pero Viegas.
      4. The relationship between Egas, Buffa, to Fonseca's family has another issue: A. A. Fernandes suggested, and José Augusto de S. Pizarro informs that is possible to accept the idea that Egas, Buffa could be Egas Gomes Barroso (Pizarro, José Augusto de S., 1997, Volume 2, pp. 610 - 611).
      The HYPOTHESIS 2, on the other hand, has documentation that allows it to be real, but the studied documentation does not show the relationships explicitly. Considering both hypotheses, it is preferred to accept Manuel Abranches de Soveral's propose. Q.E.D. (Util new documents appear that can change current understanding, because science always advances with data.).

marriages.name: Tereza de Vila Maior
history: The relationship with Teresa de Vila de Maior is cited by Leontina Ventura (dos Santos Rocha, Rui Miguel L. B., 2017, pp. 165).

children.name: Estevão Peres de Tavares
history: The documentation used to define his possible ancestors is the basis to accept this relationship. This relationship is treated as hypothetical, because there is not any documentation citing it explicitly.

children.name: Maria Peres de Tavares
history: Old genealogical books inform that she was the sister of Estevão Peres de Tavares (Felgueiras, Gaio, 1939, Tomo 14, pp. 167 ; Sousa, Manuel. et al., 1646, Dom Pedro, pp. 366). Considering the patronymic and the fact that her husband, Mem Gonçalves da Fonseca, had a shared patronate of Vila Maior with her brother (Merendeiro, Cristina João B., 2021, pp. 78, 115 ; Herculano, Alexandre, Inqvisitiones, 1860, Volvmen I, Pars II, Fascicvlvs VI, pp. 893), it is possible she is also the daughter of the suggested couple. Like her supposed brother, this relationship is treated as hypothetical, because there is not any documentation citing it explicitly.

families.name: Tavares - Portalegre
history: Descendants of Gonçalo Esteves de Tavares (Gusmão, F.A. Rodrigues de, 1867, pp. 23) that lived in Portalegre.

people.name: Pedro de Tavares
history: Nobleman of infant D. Henrique and major of Portalegre according to chancellery (Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. Afonso V, L. 34, fl. 132 (img. 267) ; Monumenta Henricina, 1969, Vol. X, pp. 240).

The chancellery of Don Afonso V also informs about the dowry given to Pedro de Tavares when he had marriage with Isabel de Sousa (Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. Afonso V, L. 37, fl. 3v (img. 14) ; Monumenta Henricina, 1969, Vol. X, pp. 175 - 177). The marriage happened, and it can be proved through the legitimation book of Leitura Nova (Torre do Tombo, Leitura Nova, Livro 2 de Legitimações, fl. 219v - 222 (img. 530 - 535)).
He was with his [hypothetical] father, Gonçalo de Tavares, during the war in Tânger (da Silva Moreira, Hugo Daniel R. G., 2009, pp. 37, 42, 47).

Pedro de Tavares was the last mayor of Portalegre from Tavares' family. This lost, however, was something not accepted so easily. Fr. Luiz de Sousa describes that before migration to Aveiro, the Tavares made an embarrassment to their king (Gusmão, F.A. Rodrigues de, 1867, pp. 26 - 27).

The available documentation always names him Pedro de Tavares, and Alão de Moraes follows them (Morais, Cristóvão Alão de, 1943-1948, Vol. 3, Tomo 2, pp. 44). On the other hand, Gaio names him in different ways: when he describes the Tavares' family names him "Pedro Esteves Tavares" (Felgueiras, Gaio, 1939, Tomo 27, pp. 154), while he cites him as "Pedro Tavares" when working with Sousa's family (Felgueiras, Gaio, 1939, Sousas, pp. 122).

marriages.name: Isabel de Sousa

children.name: Gonçalo Tavares de Sousa

children.name: Fernão de Tavares
history: If somehow Gaspar Frutuoso text can be proved, he would be a son of this couple (Gaspar, Frutuoso, 1964, Livro 4, Capítulo XV). See his description for more details.

people.name: Fernão de Tavares
history: He is not cited by genealogical books, neither it was possible to find any other document citing him. The unique available document is his grandson, Ruy Tavares, coat of arm written on December, 2nd of 1534 that says Ruy Tavares is "filho legítimo que é de Fernando Annes Tavares e neto de Fernão Tavares, de Portalegre, que foi do tronco d'esta geração e fidalgo" [legitimate son of Fernando Annes de Tavares and grandson of Fernão Tavares, from Portalegre, that was part of the trunk of this generation] (Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. João III, L. 20, fl. 194v (img. 388)).

Gaspar Frutuoso informs "Fernão de Anes Tavares, que era primo-irmão de Simão de Sousa Tavares, filhos de dois irmãos, naurais de Portalegre" [Fernão Anes Tavares, was cousin of Simão de Sousa Tavares, sons of two brothers, both from Portalegre] (Gaspar, Frutuoso, 1964, Livro 4, Capítulo XV). To check this sentence, we are not going to use the scientific method, because of cited lack of documentation that does not allow neither to confirm nor to deny it, so it is only analyzed if the HYPOTHESIS is acceptable:
  • The surnames given to Simão are not the same used in Don Manuel I chancellery, where he is cited as "Simão Tavares" during a contract of owner over a region (Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. Manuel I, L. 10, fl. 117 (img. 136)) and as "Simão Tavares de Sousa" in a letter (Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. Manuel I, L. 25, fl. 85 (img. 132)). Anselmo Braamcamp Freire follows chancellery, citing him as "Simão Tavares" (Braamcamp Freire, Anselmo, 1921, pp. 532). It is always good to remember, the reader, that surname usage was flexible during a long period of time (Monteiro, Nuno G., 2008 ; Gonçalves, Iria).
  • The "Tenças de D. Manuel I" cites Simão Tavares as a son of Gonçalo Tavares (Gomes, Saul António, 2017, pp. 129), the same happens in Dom João III's chancellery (Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. João III, L. 15, fl. 19 (img. 28)).
  • The proposed generations apparently do not have anachronism:
    • Ruy Tavares had a coat of arms in the year 1534 (Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. João III, L. 20, fl. 194v (img. 388)), and probably he was already an adult.
    • Using an inventory of year 1605 made in Brazil, that informs Fernão Dias (Paes) had "herdeiros menores de vinte e cinco anos" [heirs younger than twenty-fiver years old] (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 1, pp. 397), so it is assumed approximately that during centuries 16th and 17th, people younger than 25 years old were not considered adult.
    • Let us suppose the coat of arms was given in the same year Ruy was 25 years old, this implies he was born in 1509 (1534 - 25).
    • Analogous math can be done to estimate his father, Fernão Annes de Tavares, birth year that should be around the year of 1484 (1509 - 25).
    • Finally, we use the logic with his grandfather, Fernão de Tavares, and we arrive at the conclusion that he probably was born in the year of 1459 (1459 - 25). This date is compatible with the marriage date between Pedro de Tavares and Isabel de Sousa that probably happened in the year 1450 (Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. Afonso V, L. 37, fl. 3v (img. 14) ; Monumenta Henricina, 1969, Vol. X, pp. 175 - 177) and the fact that Fernão Tavares was younger than Gonçalo Tavares de Sousa, owner of Mira (Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. João III, L. 15, fl. 19 (img. 28)).
  • In the coat of arms, Fernão Tavares is mentioned as a nobleman (Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. João III, L. 20, fl. 194v (img. 388)) like Pedro de Tavares (Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. Afonso V, L. 34, fl. 132 (img. 267) ; Monumenta Henricina, 1969, Vol. X, pp. 240).
  • All these data show that the hypothesis only needs a document to modify its status as a fact/theory.

children.name: Fernão Eannes de Tavares
history: According to his son's coat of arm (<a href="#" onclick="htCleanSources(); htFillPrimarySource('a0fb89b0-34b3-485c-bd96-ec5c9b20d922'); return false;">Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. João III, L. 20, fl. 194v (img. 388)).

families.name: Tavares - Açores
history: Descendants of Fernão Eannes Tavares and Isabel Gonçalves de Moraes, according to Priest Gaspar Frutuoso (Gaspar, Frutuoso, 1964, Livro 4, Capítulo XV).

people.name: Fernão Eannes de Tavares
history: It was not possible to find a primary source different of his son's coat of arm (<a href="#" onclick="htCleanSources(); htFillPrimarySource('a0fb89b0-34b3-485c-bd96-ec5c9b20d922'); return false;">Torre do Tombo, Chancelaria Régia, D. João III, L. 20, fl. 194v (img. 388)), and the document does not cite his [supposed] mother.

When the Priest Gaspar Frutuoso describes him, he informs details about the reason he moved to Madeira Island, leaving Portalegre (Gaspar, Frutuoso, 1964, Livro 4, Capítulo XV). He also cites a [supposedd] marriage with an Isabel Gonçalves de Moraes, but neither him and nor his wife, descendants of noblemen, are cited years later by Henrique Henriques de Noronha (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 55 - 60, 194 - 195). There was only a citation about an "Isabel Fernandes Tavares filha de Fernão Eanes e Catarina Vaz Tavares" [Isabel Fernandes Tavares daughter of Fernão Eanes and Catarina Vaz Tavares] (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 57v, 194), but they do not look like the same.

families.name: Tavares - Queluz de Minas/Lafaiete
history: Descendant of Antonio Tavares de Mello, from Açores, and Antonia Tavares Dinis.

people.name: José Tavares de Mello
history: According to his testament, written on May, 24th of 1791, he was born in "Bom Jesus do Rabo de Peixe, Ilha Sam Miguel, Bispado de Angra" (História da Família, 2014). He arrived in Brazil before May, 6th of 1760, when he received lands in Minas Gerais (APM, Secretaria de Governo da Capitania, SC-127, fl. 169).

The surname flexibility (Monteiro, Nuno G., 2008 ; Gonçalves, Iria) also appears in José Tavares de Mello's family. To confirm this last sentence, it is assumed that José had a long life, and the cited parents in his testament were the couple Manuel Affonso and Guiomar Cabral, that had marriage on August, 15th of 1691 (Cultura Azores (2022): Livro de Casamentos Ribeira Grande 1676-1697, fl. 144). This hypothesis is reinforced with:
  • On average, women are pregnant around 23 years (Wang, Richard J., et al., 2023) and "fecundity usually ends at around 39–41 years" (Frank, O., Bianchi, P. G., & Campana, A., 1994). Using these data, if Guiomar Cabral were 22 years old when she had her marriage, she still could be pregnant around the year of 1710 [year of 1692 + 18 years (41 years - 23 years)]. We also remember the reader she could have marriage younger, and as consequence she could be pregnant after 1710.
  • If José Tavares de Mello was born either in the first or in the second decade of the 18th century, he could reach the last decade of the century alive.
  • Guiomar Cabral's father was named Antonio Tavares (Cultura Azores (2022): Livro de Casamentos Ribeira Grande 1676-1697, fl. 144), so José Tavares de Mello had his grandfather surname.
  • José Tavares de Mello's [probable] mother, Guiomar Cabral de Mello, also inherits the surname from an ancestor, to be more specific, her great-grandmother: Guiomar Cabral de Mello, daughter of Bárbara Travassos (Cultura Azores (2022): Livro de Casamentos Ribeira Grande 1676-1697, fl. 144), granddaughter of Maria Travassos (Cultura Azores (2022): Livro de Casamentos Ribeira Grande 1654-1676, fl. 115), and great-granddaughter of Guiomar Cabral de Melo (Cultura Azores (2022): Livro de Casamentos Ribeira Grande 1627-1654, fl. 59 ; de Campos, Filipe P., 2012, pp. 77).
We will show in the future, he [probably] is descendant of Fernão de Tavares.

marriages.name: Antonia Tavares Diniz
history: According to her husband's testament (História da Família, 2014) and her inventory transcribed by Quincas de Almeida (Quincas de Almeida, Livro 1, fl. 60).

families.name: Tavares - São Paulo
history: Descendant of Fernão Vieira Tavares from São Miguel - Azores (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 27, 93, 231), and one of his wives.

people.name: Fernão Vieira Tavares
history: As it was said, he is from São Miguel - Azores (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 27, 93, 231), and he is also presented as "sujeito de conhecida nobreza" [person with known nobility] (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1869, pp. 168), he also worked in noble positions while Sousas' family were owner of São Vicente (Ribeiro, Antônio Sérgio, ALESP), so he could be a descendant of Tavares and Sousas from Portalegre.

It is necessary to bring an update on previous knowledge about this family. Marta M. Amato supposed:
  • "O "Macedo" que aparece em seu nome em inúmeros documentos poderá provir de algum ancestral desconhecido; por exemplo, do seu provável avô, o Mestre de Campo Antônio Raposo Tavares, conhece-se unicamente o nome de seu pai, Fernão Vieira Tavares."

(Amato, Marta Maria, 1999, pp. 233). And there were some members of Macedo's family living in Açores, as Dr. Augusto F. do Amaral shows (Amaral, Augusto F., 2016, pp. 47, 156 - 157), but as it is shown in a descendant diligence, Macedo is the surname of Fernão Vieira Tavares's wife. Marta M. Amato's hypothesis, on the other hand, cannot be completely discarded, because Dr. Augusto F. do Amaral also shows in his work, that there is a historical relantionship between the families Macedo and Morais (Amaral, Augusto F., 2016, pp. 16 - 29, 100), so the Macedo could have some relationship with Isabel Gonçalves de Moraes, Pedro de Tavares's wife (Gaspar, Frutuoso, 1964, Livro 4, Capítulo XV), or still some ascendendant of Fernão Vieira Tavares could have a marriage with Macedo that lived in Açores.

marriages.name: Francisca Pinheiro de Macedo
history: According to witnesses and a genealogical tree available in her descendant's diligence (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 27, 62, 93, 231).

Her sister had a marriage with a man "Fulano Zurarte", that had fame to be a Jewish person, and this also brought fame to her family, but this fame did not have basis (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 5, 27, 42, 158, 231).

When José G. Salvador cites her, he names her as "Francisca Pinheiro da Costa Bravo" and also adds "também cremos ser de linhagem cristã nova" [we also believe she is from Jewish family] (Salvador, José G., 1976, pp. 145), but he says this information without to present documentation that proves she signed surname "Costa Bravo". We also highlight that José G. Salvador only says he has "crença" [belief] that she could be a Jewish person.

marriages.name: Maria da Costa
history: According to her own inquisitorial lawsuit (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício, Inquisição de Lisboa, proc. 11992, img. 1, 7).

children.name: Antonio Raposo Tavares
history: According to different witness and a family tree available in a descendant diligence (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 27, 62, 93, 231).
